alertitem.name: Cross Site Scripting (Reflected)
alertitem.desc: Cross-site Scripting (XSS) is an attack technique that involves echoing attacker-supplied code into a user's browser instance. A browser instance can be a standard web browser client, or a browser object embedded in a software product such as the browser within WinAmp, an RSS reader, or an email client. The code itself is usually written in HTML/JavaScript, but may also extend to VBScript, ActiveX, Java, Flash, or any other browser-supported technology.
alertitem.solution: Phase: Architecture and Design - Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.
alertitem.otherinfo: User-controlled input is reflected in the response without proper encoding.

alertitem.name: Cross Site Scripting (Persistent)
alertitem.desc: Cross-site Scripting (XSS) is stored on the server and executed when users access affected pages.
alertitem.solution: Validate all user input and encode output properly.
alertitem.otherinfo: Persistent XSS found in user profile bio field.

alertitem.name: Missing Anti-CSRF Tokens
alertitem.desc: No Anti-CSRF tokens were found in a HTML submission form. A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent.
alertitem.solution: Implement anti-CSRF tokens for all state-changing operations.
alertitem.otherinfo: No known Anti-CSRF token found in form.

alertitem.name: Cross-Domain Misconfiguration
alertitem.desc: Web browser data loading may be possible, due to a Cross Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) misconfiguration on the web server.
alertitem.solution: Ensure that sensitive data is not available in an unauthenticated manner. Configure CORS headers properly.
alertitem.otherinfo: The CORS misconfiguration allows any domain to make requests.

alertitem.name: X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing
alertitem.desc: The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'.
alertitem.solution: Set X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all responses.
alertitem.otherinfo: This header should be set on all responses containing user controllable content.

alertitem.name: Strict-Transport-Security Header Not Set
alertitem.desc: HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) is a web security policy mechanism whereby a web server declares that complying user agents (such as a web browser) are to interact with it using only secure HTTPS connections.
alertitem.solution: Set the Strict-Transport-Security header on HTTPS responses.

alertitem.name: Weak Authentication Method
alertitem.desc: HTTP basic or digest authentication has been used over an insecure connection. The credentials can be read and then reused by someone with access to the network.
alertitem.solution: Use HTTPS for all authentication. Consider using stronger authentication mechanisms like OAuth2 or JWT.
alertitem.otherinfo: Basic authentication credentials transmitted without encryption.

alertitem.name: CSP: Wildcard Directive
alertitem.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. The following directives either allow wildcard sources or are missing.
alertitem.solution: Configure Content Security Policy with specific, restrictive directives.
alertitem.otherinfo: CSP header present but uses wildcard directive which defeats the purpose.
